timeline.author: JonLavi

timeline.bodyText:
We don't generally add the files directly from the source code, but set up the settings.gradle file to download these when the gradle run task is started. Check out this example:
https://github.com/Esri/arcgis-runtime-samples-java/blob/master/editing/edit-and-sync-features/settings.gradle#L6-L16
There should be a link to the location of the file on ArcGIS Online (AGOL) in the sample's design.
The correct path for it would then be /resources/edit_features_with_feature_linked_annotation/<possibly some other folder>.
Whereas the last folder might be the result of a folder within the archive coming from AGOL (or none!).
timeline.author: JonLavi

replies.bodyText:
@JonLavi @sclaridge just to note the above path for storing samples data is incorrect!
/resources/sample_name should be for UI/style files (.fxml/css) only. Any samples data needs to be stored in a samples-data directory. You can see this pattern in the edit and sync features sample that Jon referred to above.
e.g. for your sample
    ant.unzip(
            src: file("./data.zip"),
            dest: file("./samples-data/loudon")
    )
replies.author: Rachael-E

timeline.author: JonLavi
JonLavi

timeline.bodyText:
For your methods, it's common practice to put @param descriptions of the parameters in the JavaDoc above method descriptions.
Intellij Top tip: you can auto-generate a template by writing /** in the line above a method signature, then hitting return. All you'll have to do is then fill in the descriptions. The rest of your methods would need updating as well.
I think they should also be written in active voice, e.g. Creates/Moves, etc. But not 100% sure.
timeline.author: JonLavi

timeline.bodyText:
I think we need to put the remaining code (line 50 onwards) inside this try statements, since if we fail to load the fxml loader, we won't want to execute any of the other code, as we don't have access to any of these FXML defined javafx objects.
It seems like our other samples don't do this though, so let's do some research on this which is the correct pattern!
timeline.author: JonLavi

replies.author: sclaridge

replies.bodyText:
Good spot on these!

However, if I remove the try catch entirely and have EditAttributesDialog throw the Exception, it can be handled in showEditableAttributes():

I don't think it's a good idea to handle the exceptions in a different method, at least in the context of a sample. Best we keep the complexity to a minimum there.
So, looks like what you had originally was correct. Let's just leave it as is then 👍
replies.author: JonLavi

timeline.author: JonLavi

replies.bodyText: As I mentioned in the comment on your questions, we also have the possibility to have the Dialog return the data to edit back to the main Controller class, and then do the updateFeatureAsync call back in there. In hindsight that might actually be the better way forward. Then we'd abstract away the data input through the UI, but keep the Runtime API call to updateFeatureAsync within the main class.
replies.author: JonLavi

timeline.bodyText:
Looks like every time we call clearSelection(), we also do selectedFeature = null. So it would be possible to put that statement in the method as well.
We could also pop the statement selectedFeatureIsPolyline = false; in the method as well, although it's not necessary to set that boolean every time.

timeline.bodyText:
Nice work on tidying this up.
I've had a closer look and there's actually no need to return the selected feature here. This is because there's a handle on it in the main sample code already (from when we run mapView.identifyLayersAsync). So for the sake of simplicty let's convert back to return null;

timeline.author: JonLavi

timeline.bodyText:
I'm not the documentation expert, but I have the impression we usually start @param descriptions with the, and describe these parameters based on their context within the function. So we could write here:

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
               * @param screenPoint location the user clicked
          
          
            
               * @param screenPoint the screen point at which to select a feature, or to move a feature to
timeline.author: JonLavi

timeline.bodyText:
Another documentation suggestion: we can describe what purpose this parameter serves within the method:

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
               * @param screenPoint location the user clicked
          
          
            
               * @param screenPoint the screen point at which to identify a feature

timeline.bodyText: perhaps this would be better named as "updateButton"? We could also update the button text to show "Update" which is perhaps a bit clearer than "Ok" in terms of what the user is doing if they click to edit the feature.
timeline.author: Rachael-E

timeline.bodyText: all of these can be local variables in the start method, since they are not referenced elsewhere in the class. We don't need to worry about these being garbage collected, since we're not waiting for them to finish loading before doing something with them.
timeline.author: Rachael-E
Rachael-E
Rachael-E
Rachael-E

timeline.bodyText: I think for a readability perspective, it makes more sense for us to move this loadAsync call up (to above the geodatabase.addDoneLoadingListener() even though it doesn't make much of a difference from a code execution perspective.
